Report with R Markdown

Thomas Huet, University of Oxford

Introduction

  • R Markdown
  • Example
  • AFDS

R Markdown is an authoring framework for data science (AFDS). It combines :

  • R code chunks

  • Narrative parts with – mainly – Markdown syntax

Note

R Markdown = .Rmd = + for Markdown

AFDS are used to create data-driven documents (reports) with a notebook interface

AFDS Language Description
Rmarkdown R front-end oriented
Jupyter Python back-end oriented
D3.js JavaScript web oriented
Plotly


Academic reporting

R Markdown is often enough for academic reporting. It supports:

  • HTML/CSS markup languages
  • LaTeX writing
  • BibTex references
  • interactive maps
  • 3D plots
  • etc.

Main packages

knitr engine for dynamic report generation with R (e.g. convert to LaTeX)
rmarkdown convert R Markdown documents into a variety of formats, extension of {knitr}
bookdown advanced editing and publishing functions (e.g. cross referencing)

New document

  • Create
  • RStudio preview
  • GitHub preview
  • Knit

In RStudio: File > New file > R Markdown...

Options (Title, Author, Date, etc.) can be changed later (YAML header). Choose PDF as the default output format.

Note

A new document is created.

Run the new document with knitr , it will launch the render



RStudio tools

  • Tools
  • Visual R Markdown

tool description
knit automatically when save the document
check spelling
knit the document
run Visual R Markdown + other options
new code chunk (R, Bash, D3, Python, etc.)
run a part or the whole document
publish the document
run Visual R Markdown


Visual R Markdown has a Pandoc syntax (extension of Mardown), supports Zotero , can retrieve complete bibliographical references from DOI or searches on PubMed , Crossref , and DataCite

Document structure

R Markdown combines

header YAML
a YAML header with metadata

code chunk
R code chunks

narrative part
Markdown narrative parts

Markdown syntax

Easy-to-write plain text syntax

  • Used by
  • Syntax
  • Online editor
  • Online converter

Different code-oriented frameworks: Jupyter , GitHub , Google Doc , Sketchfab , Slack , Stackoverflow , etc.

https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/authoring_basics.html

https://stackedit.io/app#

Pandoc is an extension of Markdown, usefull for text conversions (Markdown <-> HTML, LaTeX <-> Markdown, etc.)

https://pandoc.org/try/

Converters

With Pandoc, exists a lot of online apps making the conversions easier (e.g. Word to HTML).


Styling

  • Text
  • Math formula
  • Others
  • with HTML and CSS
Markdown Rendered
**bold**, __bold__ bold, bold
*italic*, _italic_ italic, italic
code code
hyphen -- inserted -- in a sentence hyphen – inserted – in a sentence
H~2~O H2O
10^−19^ 10−19
… …
Markdown Rendered
$$\sum_{i=1}^{n} X^3_i$$ \[\sum_{i=1}^{n} X^3_i\]
… …

narrative part

> I am a blockquote

I am a blockquote

line separator

narrative part

---

A extended part of the text styling can also be done with HTML/CSS

narrative part

<h2 style="color:blue;">A Blue Heading</h2>
<p style="color:red;">A red paragraph.</p>

A Blue Heading

A red paragraph.

List

  • Numbered
  • Unnumbered

narrative part

- Numbered  
  1. first element
  2. second element
  • Numbered
    1. first element
    2. second element


narrative part

- Unnumbered
  * first element
  * second element
  * third element
    - third element - sub 1
      + third element - sub 1 - subsub 1
      + third element - sub 1 - subsub 2
  • Unnumbered
    • first element
    • second element
    • third element
      • third element - sub 1
        • third element - sub 1 - subsub 1
        • third element - sub 1 - subsub 2

Tables

  • Simple table
  • Alignements
  • Complex tables
  • Hint

narrative part

| Header 1 | Header 2 |
| --- | ----------- |
| Row 1 | Text |
| Row 2 | Another text |
or

narrative part

| Header 1    | Header 2    |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| Row 1       | Text        |
| Row 2       | Another text|


gives the same result :


Header 1 Header 2
Row 1 Text
Row 2 Another text

Use :----:, :---, or ---: to align

narrative part

| Left        |    Center   |         Right |
| :---        |    :----:   |          ---: |
| Header      | Title       | Here's this   |
| Paragraph   | Text        | And more      |
Left Center Right
Header Title Here’s this
Paragraph Text And more

Complex tables needs are created inside code chunks, e.g. kable() from {knitr} with kable_styling() from {kableExtra}

code chunk

library(kableExtra)
dt <- mtcars[1:5, 1:6]
dtt <- dt %>%
  kbl() %>%
  kable_paper("hover", full_width = F, font_size = 20)
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt
Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160 110 3.90 2.620
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 6 160 110 3.90 2.875
Datsun 710 22.8 4 108 93 3.85 2.320
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 6 258 110 3.08 3.215
Hornet Sportabout 18.7 8 360 175 3.15 3.440

code chunk

dtt <- dt %>%
  kbl(caption = "Recreating booktabs style table") %>%
  kable_classic(full_width = F, html_font = "Cambria", font_size = 20)
Recreating booktabs style table
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt
Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160 110 3.90 2.620
Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 6 160 110 3.90 2.875
Datsun 710 22.8 4 108 93 3.85 2.320
Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 6 258 110 3.08 3.215
Hornet Sportabout 18.7 8 360 175 3.15 3.440

Spaces and end of lines

  • Spaces
  • End of line

Extra spaces (HTML only)

  •   &emsp; means 4 spaces (= a tabulation)
  •   &ensp; means 2 spaces
  •   &nbsp; means 1 space

End of line (<br> in HTML) with 2 or more spaces and return – or \ and return – for example:

narrative part

Reconnais-toi  
Cette adorable personne c'est toi  
Sous le grand chapeau canotier  
Oeil
Nez  
Ta Bouche  
Voici l’ovale de ta figure  
Ton cou Exquis  
(Apollinaire, 1913)

Cross-referencing

  • Concept
  • Variables
  • Figures

Locators to cite and reuse variables (figures, sections, etc.)

Variables calculated inside the code chunks can be called in the narrative part:

code chunk

library(archdata)
data("Handaxes")
number.of.axes <- nrow(Handaxes)

narrative part

Furze Platt dataset counts 'r number.of.axes' axes

Furze Platt dataset counts 600 axes

—

Variables can be also be calculated outside code chunks (not recommended), with an inline R code:

narrative part

Furze Platt dataset counts 'r number.of.axes' axes described BY 'r ncol(Handaxes)' variables. The maximal length (L = 'r max(Handaxes$L)')

Furze Platt dataset counts 600 axes described by 8 variables. The maximal length (L = 242)

Warning

Here the ` quote has been changed to a ’ quote for display purpose


code chunk

{r maxLmaxB, echo=TRUE, fig.align="center", fig.cap= "Axes L/B ratio"}
library(archdata)
data("Handaxes")
plot(Handaxes$L, Handaxes$B)
model <- lm(B ~ L, data = Handaxes)
abline(lm(model))

narrative part

the distribution of the maximum length (L) and maximum breadth (B) shows a R^2^ = 'r round(model$coefficients[2], 2)',  Fig. \@ref(fig:maxLmaxB))

🗘the distribution of the maximum length (L) and maximum breadth (B) shows a R2 = 0.42, Fig. @ref(fig:maxLmaxB))

Note

Here the ` quote has been changed to a ’ quote for display purpose

Note

Here the figure callout \@ref(fig:maxLmaxB)) is not rendered because this document is a Quarto presentation using {revealjs} instead of {bookdown}


Bibliographic references

  • in YAML
  • references.bib
  • Cross citation
  • BibTex

BibTex, or .bib, is a plain text format for bibliographic references.

This file is referenced in the YAML header.

code in R Markdown Render
@Xie22 Xie (2022)
[@Xie18] (Xie, Allaire, and Grolemund 2018)
[credits: @Xie20] (credits: Xie, Dervieux, and Riederer 2020)
published by Yihui Xie [-@Xie19; -@Xie22] published by Yihui Xie (2019, 2022)
… …

narrative part

published by Yihui Xie [-@Xie19]

published by Yihui Xie (2019)

It’s easy to retrieve this reference in Google Scholar, and paste it in the .bib file.

Code chunks

R code chunks are placeholders for the coding part of the document, expressed with a local header, and a body part.

Headers

  • Headers options
  • Options hierarchy

code chunk

{r munsingenspat, echo = TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}

Options are used to show/hide the code, change the size of the output image, set the alignment of the ouptut, etc.

https://github.com/zoometh/thomashuet/blob/main/teachings/stats/R4Archaeo/temp.pdf

code chunk

{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)

The 🔝 chunk in the document allows to set these options for all other chunks unless you change these options in the following code chunks headers

Tools

tool description
graphical interface for options
run the previous chunks but not this one
run this chunk

Code evaluation

code chunk

{r munsingenspat, echo = TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}
code description
include = FALSE prevents code and results from appearing in the finished file. R Markdown still runs the code in the chunk, and the results can be used by other chunks.
echo = FALSE prevents code, but not the results from appearing in the finished file.
message = FALSE prevents messages that are generated by code from appearing in the finished file.
warning = FALSE prevents warnings that are generated by code from appearing in the finished.

Graphical options

code chunk

{r munsingenspat, fig.height = 10, fig.with = 10}
code description
fig.cap = "..." adds a caption to graphical results.
fig.height = 7 height for plots created by the chunk (in inches).
fig.width = 7 width for plots created by the chunk (in inches).
fig.align = default how to align graphics in the final document. One of 'left', 'right', or 'center'.
fig.pos = 'H' fix the output exactly here.

Body

The body of a code chunk is where you place the R code

code chunk

{r munsingenspat, echo=TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}
library(dplyr)
library(leaflet)
munsingen.long <- 7.569587484129203
munsingen.lat <- 46.864709895956004
leaflet(width = "60%", height = "400px") %>%
  addTiles(group = 'OSM') %>%
  addControl("Munsingen necropolis", position = "bottomright") %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$Esri.WorldImagery, group='Esri.WorldImagery') %>%
  addMarkers(munsingen.long,
             munsingen.lat,
             label = "Munsingen necropolis") %>%
  addLayersControl(
    baseGroups = c('OSM', 'Esri.WorldImagery')) %>%
  addScaleBar(position = "bottomleft")

Images

Images can be render inside a code chunk:

code chunk

knitr::include_graphics("www/munsingen_fib_measures.png")

YAML

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: '2023-02-05'
---

This is the document header, it contains the metadata (e.g, title), the document output format (e.g, pdf) and configuration (e.g. table of content). It is composed on key - value pairs:

YAML dates

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: "'r format(Sys.time(), '%D')'"
---

02/08/23

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: "'r format(Sys.time(), '%d %B %Y')'"
---

08 February 2023

Warning

Here the ` quote has been changed to a ’ quote for display purpose


YAML output

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  pdf_document
---

Select the output format, here a PDF: https://github.com/zoometh/thomashuet/blob/main/teachings/stats/R4Archaeo/temp.pdf

YAML table of content

Table of content (TOC)

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  html_document:
    toc: true
    toc_depth: 2
    toc_float:
      collapsed: false
      smooth_scroll: false
---

YAML references

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: "08 February 2023"
bibliography: references.bib
---

Reference the bibliographic file (e.g. references.bib). Here in the same folder as the .Rmd file.

see Xie et al. (2018)

Styling

  • HTML/CSS
  • In the document
  • In a CSS file

HTML/CSS can be use in all parts of the document

code chunk

...
water.values <- paste0("<b>", Oxford.water$Place, "</b><br>", 
                       "Observed: ", Oxford.water$OxfordPct)
water.residuals <- paste0("<b>", Oxford.water$Place, "</b><br>",
                          "Observed: ", round(Oxford.water$predicted, 2))
...
          add_trace(name = "Regression line", x = ~OxfordDst, y = fitted(lm.water),
                    mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'darkgrey', width = 1.5),
                    text = ~paste0("R<sup>2</sup>: ", round(r2.water, 2)),
                    hoverinfo = 'text') %>%
...
        layout(title = paste0('Oxford pottery with a probable <b>no water</b> ', 
                              'transportation <br> (R<sup>2</sup> = ', r2.nowater, ")"),
...


narrative part

<span style='font-size: 60px'>Big font</span>

Big font

narrative part

<b>bolded</b>

bolded

narrative part

<span style="color:red">red</span>

red

Use a CSS file to customize styles

https://github.com/zoometh/thomashuet/blob/main/teachings/stats/R4Archaeo/styles.css

This file is called inside the YAML header of the document:

header YAML

---
title: "Report with R Markdown"
subtitle: "Report data analysis with R Markdown authoring framework"
author: "Thomas Huet, University of Oxford"
format:
  revealjs: 
    slide-number: true
    chalkboard: true
    scrollable: true
    logo: www/inst-uni-oxford_.png
    css: styles.css
    margin: 0.01
bibliography: references.bib
pagetitle: Report with R Markdown
---

Here in the same folder as the .Rmd file. Do:

narrative part

Customize with CSS like this <notes>**dodgerblue** background</notes>.

🗘 Customize with CSS like this dodgerblue background.

Interactivity

  • Shiny
  • Leaflet
  • Plotly

Shiny offers a framework to create interactive documents

header YAML

runtime: shiny

Note

Try: File > New File > Rmarkdown > Shiny, or in the YAML header. There are different ways to use Shiny in R Markdown, for example by embedding an HTML widget created by Shiny outside the R Markdown document, or by embedding the Shiny coding directly.


Maps with package

code chunk

library(dplyr)
library(leaflet)
munsingen.long <- 7.569587484129203
munsingen.lat <- 46.864709895956004
leaflet(width = "90%", height = "300px") %>%
  addTiles(group = 'OSM') %>%
  addControl("Munsingen necropolis", position = "bottomright") %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$Esri.WorldImagery, group='Esri.WorldImagery') %>%
  addMarkers(munsingen.long,
             munsingen.lat,
             label = "Munsingen necropolis") %>%
  addLayersControl(
    baseGroups = c('OSM', 'Esri.WorldImagery')) %>%
  addScaleBar(position = "bottomleft")

2D plots with the package

code chunk

library(plotly)
library(dplyr)
library(archdata)
data("Fibulae")
Fibulae.ex <- Fibulae
Fibulae.ex$lbl <- paste0("<b>Museum num.: ", Fibulae.ex$Mno, "</b><br>",
                          "Length: ", Fibulae.ex$Length, "<br>",
                          "Foot Angle: ", Fibulae.ex$FA, "<br>")
plot_ly(data = Fibulae.ex, 
        x = ~Length,
        y = ~FA,
        text = ~lbl,
        hoverinfo = "text")

Export document

Export R Markdown in: HTML, PDF, LaTeX, Word, ODT, RTF, Markdown, etc.

HTML

HTML export is the default option of a R Markdown document.

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output: html_document
---

PDF

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output: pdf_document
---

Note

For advanced editing, read below

is useful in R Markdown for chunk calls, and more generally for cross-referencing. PDF uses LaTeX syntax, if you don’t have MiKTeX installed, you need to install the package (Xie 2019).

install.packages('tinytex')
tinytex::install_tinytex()
# .rs.restartR()

To export in PDF, use bookdown::pdf_document2: and knit.

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  bookdown::pdf_document2:
    css: styles.css
    toc: yes
    toc_depth: 4
    toc_float:
      collapsed: no
bibliography: references.bib
---

These temporary files are creates:

At the end of the rendering, these files are deleted.

LaTeX

LaTeX (extension of TeX) is a rich plain text syntax for academic writing. To export in TeX, select in the YAML header a PDF export + keep tex:

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  bookdown::pdf_document2: 
    keep_tex: true
---

Publishing

  • On Rpubs
  • On GitHub and GitLab

On , after Render:

https://rpubs.com/

On GitHub , or GitLab , the same document, or related documents, are accessibles by different means:

Practice

  • Objective
  • Data
  • Output

Note

The practical part has an estimated duration of 60 minutes

Use R Markdown (code chunks and narrative text) to create a report. Choice between:

  • improvement of the existing .Rmd model for the fibulae from the Münsingen cemetery

  • select another dataset from the {archdata} package (e.g. ‘Handaxes’), to improve the .Rmd template

Download the files from the practice/ folder:

https://github.com/zoometh/thomashuet/tree/main/teachings/stats/R4Archaeo/practice

You can use this website:

https://download-directory.github.io/

or go here and download, or copy/paste the .Rmd file and the .bib file.
